thread.title: Little heroes create new jam in the test kitchens of Spring Gully Foods | The
thread.title_full: Little heroes create new jam in the test kitchens of Spring Gully Foods | The Advertiser

author: NIGEL AUSTIN
title: Little heroes create new jam in the test kitchens of Spring Gully Foods | The
text:
STRAWBERRY, mango and passionfruit are being jammed together in a taste sensation to appeal to kids (and adults) this summer.
The test kitchens of Spring Gully Foods have blended the jam, one of five selected by children supported by the Little Heroes Foundation, all of which will be developed and trialled by retailers with the most popular jams going on sale in summer.
Jed, 12, Holly, 8, Lily, 6, and Connor, 6 spent the morning at Spring Gully’s Dry Creek facility creating their favourite jam.
A proportion of sales will go towards Little Heroes Foundation’s $4 million Centre for Robotics and Innovation, due to open at the Women’s and Children’s Hospital this year.
Little Heroes Foundation’s Natalie Von Bertouch said it was an exciting way to raise vital funds for seriously ill kids.
“It’s fantastic we can team up with another great South Australian organisation to help children who need it most,” Ms Von Bertouch said.
The centre will feature a world-class robotic gymnasium for children and adolescents being treated for serious illnesses to help them get back on their feet.
It will also conduct a five-year clinical research study to uncover new ways to help children re-learn everyday tasks.
